going to go all that sort of thing can't we do a little bit better than that and this is where we come to webpack Dev
middleware this is a feature of webpack where the compiler for webpack instead of exiting when it's finished it can
stay in memory and it can keep all the intermediate compilation states there so that it's ready to recompile very
quickly uh using all the cached intermediate States and it can also expose a kind of it's a bit like a
virtual file system that represents the output from the compiler and then we can
serve that virtual file system to the browser so the browser is always seeing the compiled output even though it's not
even on disk and it's enough to say that if a request comes in well compilation is in progress it will just block it
until it's got a consistent set of files so you can just hit refresh as soon as you like it will probably be done more
or less instantly because it was already in memory but even if not it will wait the right amount of time before completing the request so how can we use
that well we have made that available in these templates in fact it's enabled by default but I just took it out just

file new project you would see some lines of code in there already like this this says uh if it's if we're in

you could do this in production but there isn't really much of a good reason to be dynamically recompiling your

bet it's not a very well-known term in Microsoft circles basically the idea is that you've got the code that you write
and then you've got all the third party Library code which in this case would be angular two and bootstrap and some other stuff probably now the third party code
is tends to be massive compared with yours for example angular 2 on its own
even after minification is 1.9 megabytes it's massive and to compile that webpack
has to do tons of static analysis over it all to link all these modules together and uh figure out you know if
it all if it all builds correctly and that in this case is taking 15 seconds you don't want to wait that amount of
time every time you make any change to your own code so with the vendoring system we can split that into a separate

or an isomorphic app or whatever you want to call it basically can we take all of the JavaScript for your

users realistically you probably are not going to support this scenario the main reason why this is actually useful is
just for the sheer performance of having your application rendered really quickly so the application loads essentially
instantly there's never there's no loading stage as far as the client is concerned it's pre-rendered on the server and then in the background the
client side code is um loading and as soon as it's loaded then it takes over and the client side logic works exactly
like it normally would okay so that is doing some pre-rendering on the server
okay now there are uh quite a few other features that are in these templates
that I'm not going to have time to demonstrate in too much detail so I'm just going to skip through a few of them now one of them is a feature called cach
priming this is another performance feature the idea here is that there's a very common pattern in single page apps
where you render your initial UI and send it down to the browser and then the very first thing the browser does is it
makes an Ajax request back to the server to fetch some data which is not that smart really because if the server knew
the client was going to ask for that data Why didn't it just send that data in the initial page that would have saved an entire HTTP request so the idea
of cash priming is that you can uh specify a list of uh end points in your
MVC application that the client is going to make a request to and then we will pre-evaluate those requests embed them
in the page and then whenever the client side code was going to make an Ajax request to that endpoint we will
intercept it and give it the data that we've already got and it will just resolve the request immediately without even talking to the server so it's just
a simple performance feature that uh We've also got some helpers for validation as you can probably guess
angular 2 has got a client side validation thing as well as react and well you know everything's got
validation and you can't really get away from that and on the server uh in ASP now obviously you've got a server side
validation feature as well uh in terms of uh angular we found that it was necessary to have a bit of helper logic
to make these two things play together nicely so if you have a server side validation message you want it to appear
at the right place in an angular 2 form well we've got some helpers to make sure that actually happens uh and then
another feature lazy loading this is a feature that's unique to The Knockout template at the moment uh we would be
very happy to have that feature in the angular and react and any other templates as well as long as somebody can come up with a plausible way of
doing it with those we just haven't found one yet but for The Knockout one it's very straightforward the basically the idea is that as part of the bill
process uh you can nominate some different parts of your application that will be split off uh by webpack into
separate bundles you don't even have to think about giving names to them or anything else you just Define a certain navigation point and the code that's
reached from that will go into a separate bundle on dis with some autogenerated name and then it will
automatically get loaded on demand as the user navigates around so it's completely transparent to the user it just means that you're not shipping the
whole application up front you're just sending it incrementally as the user moves around okay so that's a bunch of

strictly speaking tied to react but it's very often used with react because it kind of came out of that and works very
well with it the idea of react is of Redux is that it's it tracks the all the
states that your application has been through and the way that it's transitioned between each of these
states and the benefit of doing that is that you can always understand the state that your application is in if
something's goes wrong you can trace backwards through all the different transitions that it's been to and see
exactly what caused whatever particular thing to go wrong actually caused it

use of yet another new get package called node services and as you can probably guess from the name the way
that works is that it makes use of nodejs internally so internally in a hidden headless way
it spins up instances of node.js whenever it needs to and it's got a very fast RPC layer that allows it to pass
invocations into node.js and get the result out and it deals with all the messy stuff around process lifetime
management recovery from errors propagating errors that have occurred in node through into your net application
in the right kind of way uh all the serialization and and all that kind of stuff so that you don't have to deal with that and you can make use of these
